ANSWER: Based on the diagnosis of Von Willebrand Disease, I recommend a comprehensive treatment approach that combines evidence-based medical management with patient-centered care strategies. The treatment plan includes initiating desmopressin therapy in responsive patients with vigilant monitoring of serum sodium and blood pressure. For patients unresponsive to DDAVP or with more severe disease, VWF concentrates should be utilized to effectively manage bleeding episodes. Supportive measures such as avoiding trauma, protective behaviors, and patient education on bleeding recognition are essential. Long-term management involves regular hematology follow-up to assess bleeding frequency, laboratory VWF levels, and adherence, with patient education tailored to address their stoic and minimizer tendencies. Immediate actions include arranging hematology consultation and providing instructions on medication use and bleeding precautions. Short-term goals encompass stabilization of bleeding symptoms and patient understanding, while long-term objectives focus on minimizing bleeding risk and maintaining quality of life. This strategy aims to effectively control bleeding, prevent complications, and empower the patient to participate actively in their care.
